DIV1.HEAD: THE Sisters Complaint For the Decay of the GALLANTS.
To the Tune of, Will Womens Vanities never have End.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: YE Geudly Sisters! have a care
How you these Gallants trust,
A sadder Tale you ne're did hear,
Then now unfold, I must.
It hapned lately that a Fair Maid,
In London, would have set up her Trade,
But by a Gallant was made a Jade.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: She thought him able, to perform
What e're he undertook,
And knew he could do her no harm,
For all his Lofty Look.
She was in hopes to have enough,
But when it came unto the proof,
This Gallant went out like a Candle Snuff.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: First at the Tavern, they did move
Their Active Bloods, with Wine.
She saw that this would not improve,
Or further her design;
With that she Thought if this would not do 'it,
They'd have a Dram of Brandy to boot,
The Dev'l's in't then if he come not to't.

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: So hand in hand away they went,
To see how this would take,
And stayd not long for the Event,
Such Courage Brandies make.
For they had not been long at the Platter,
But at him, her Mouth did water,
And he, was eager to be at her.

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: They had no opportunity,
To play their Loving Game,
But where another Girl did lye,
No matter for her Name.
Who it seems did play Bo-peep,
Or, as they call it, slept Dog-sleep,
Because she did their Reckoning keep.

LG.HEAD: VI.
LG.L: They did enjoy their wisht content,
Within the Naked Bed.
But e're her brisk desire was spent,
The Gallant, he, was Dead.
Yet, in an hour, it is well known,
He was but fower times up and down,
If none but such Men serve the Town.

DIV1.P: LONDON, Printed for J. E. at the Marigold near Salsbury Court in Fleetstreet. 1684.
